Juego bastante curiso. Se trata de un juego de puzzles que se basa en los circuitos musicales. Habra fragmentos perdidos que deberas meter de nuevo en el circuito para que la canción que estas reconstruyendo suene exactamente igual a la original. 

Se te proporcionaran varios tipos de herramientas, como loops para las piezas, loops para secuencias, varios circuitos con solo uno de ellos validos... Ademas si te atascas podras usar una herramienta que te diga que parte esta mal colocada, y habra otra que te coloque una pieza bien.

La musica que debes reconstruir es electronica, pero no "sucia" o "discotequera", sino bastante relajante y melodica, en algunos casos bastante epica. Se puede decir que la musica esta bastante bien. Los graficos son sencillos y minimalistas, pero acompañan muy bien al juego.

Hay que decir que dura poco, y si tienes buen oido aun se te hara mas corto. Si no te va demasiado la musica o los puzzles, pues como es obvio no te gustara. Pero si te gustan los puzzles, la musica, jugar relajado y pasar un buen rato, aqui tienes un juego para tener en cuenta.

11645126.review:
Playing Circuits is like trying to transcribe a song someone else wrote, while having an overly vague and harsh on looker constantly jump in to tell you you're doing something wrong. It's a dull lesson in tedious frustration, constantly imposing illogical and repetitive mechanics on the player while providing no incentive or reward for figuring them out. The ideas behind Circuits sound intriguing on paper, but the foundation developer Digital Tentacle has laid them out is simply not there.

Circuits is a game about building music, or that's what it's supposed to be. In reality it's the act of memorizing a sequence of sounds, and then placing audio samples in the correct order until you've recreated the track exactly. This is expanded upon by new mechanics such as repeating samples and loops, but they are never used in a way that actually expands the gameplay into something more compelling, instead only making tracks more confusing and difficult to put together.

This is the fault of both the opaque design at the core of Circuits, and the fact that the tracks you are creating are often made up of far more sounds and layers than you actually place on your board. This makes deciphering what sample is meant to go where incredibly challenging in a way that feels poorly thought out and rarely allows you to readily hear the mistakes you make, as everything is buried under so many other sounds to begin with. It also flies in the face of the very premise of the game that you are building these tracks yourself, as so much of them are completely separate from the gameplay and simply added onto the samples you placed. Finally the soundtrack is enormously disappointing for a game based around music, consisting of twenty-five nearly identical tracks, none of which are the least bit memorable and made having to listen to them dozens of times per level immensely irritating.

Though it blends two of my favorite genres (music and puzzle games), Circuits manages nothing but to be exceedingly unenjoyable in nearly every aspect of its designing, failing to even deliver upon its original goals as it meanders about with uneasy steps in its mess of dismal design choices. I'm not sure why I bothered to push through to the end, as having done so I can see I was having very much the same experience then as right at the start of the game, which is to say a dreadful time that I couldn't recommend to others.

11631077.review:
Wow.  just finished this game. It didn't take long; about two or three hours with breaks.   I put on my Westone 4R earbuds, EQed up the base a smidge, dimmed the lights and just blissed out.   This reminds me of so many other games,  Auditorium comes to mind first, FLoW comes second... However, this game's simple backgrounds, ambient music and level sounds provide a pure FLOW-like experience are simply wonderful.

It's a short game, but oh so fulfilling.  The first time a tune came together, a tear came to my eye.  If you're going to play this with desktop speakers, or those crappy iPhone earbuds that people insist on using because "they came with my iPhone, so they must be good, right?", just don't.  This game warrants GOOD headphones.   Also, if you're going to play this in a busy environment, again, don't. Go somewhere quiet, dim the lights and just relax.

The game makes you rebuild a song which has been 'split' into component tracks and pieces.  It's a bit like trying to guess the ingredients and method of  chocolate cake, by repeatedly eating a forkful until you have it right...   Although you play with individual elements, when the whole thing comes together, with the orchestral backing, it's just wonderful.

I can't think of a negative thing to say about the game, actually.  There was no point where I felt "out of the flow".  The controls are wonderful, the quality of the sound effects and music are perfect.  I'm really glad I had the opportunity to experience this.   10/10.

11521071.review:
Not a bad game.  Circuits is kind of a puzzle game for musicians.  The game plays a small musical piece and this instrumental piece is layered so that each layer is a different part of what you're hearing.  The drum beats on one layer, high tones on another layer and then chords on another, (that kind of thing) all make up everything you're hearing.  You can listen to the musical piece all together or you can listen to it each layer at a time.

The game plays a short piece of music that you can graphically see run like a time line on the screen and you're supposed to replicate what you're hearing with the buttons and tools placed within that time line.  If you can't remember the musical piece that was played... the game will play it again and you can listen to each layer so you can zero in on the part you can't remember.

Like I said, it's not a bad game.  However; I found the game to drag a bit because sometimes the part you need to remember is at the end of the timeline and you have to listen to the whole thing just to get to that last part of the time line.  If you zero in on that one layer... and there's nothing happening 'til the end... you have to listen to the whole thing in basic silence 'til you get to that one part.  It makes the game drag.  A fast forward button (like the one that's used when you find a solution to the puzzle) would solve the problem.

I'd recommend the game for musicians out there who are prolly used to analyzing music and breaking down the layers of what you're hearing but I think others will get bored real quick waiting the time line out.  I found myself wanting an FF button within 5 minutes.  I got the game SUPER cheap so buy it on sale if you do buy.

11459079.review:
Circuits é um puzzle indie, em meio a centenas de jogos do mesmo gênero produzidos a um ritmo quase diário. O que faz Circuits ser tão diferente, então? Bem, para começar, ao invés dos olhos, são nossos ouvidos que devem reagir ao estímulo do jogo.

(...)

O objetivo de cada puzzle é completar uma pista de áudio. Para isso, o jogador deve ouvir com atenção cada pedaço da música, e colocá-lo em uma ordem coerente. Todas as faixas são originais, e brilhantemente produzidas por David Garcia; as referências passam pela música eletrônica, e vão até a música clássica. O layout de Cesar Sampedro é extremamente intuitivo, e inclui apenas linhas e círculos; enquanto os círculos representam os fragmentos de sons, a linha indica o caminho de progressão da música completa. O terceiro integrante do estúdio Digital Tentacle, Cesar Botana, foi inteiramente responsável pela programação do jogo.

(...)

A dificuldade pode ser aumentada ou diminuída a depender da vontade do jogador; Circuits dá a opção de utilizar um sistema de dicas, um sistema de ajuda que coloca uma das peças sonoras do lugar correto, e um sistema que permite escutar diferentes instrumentos musicais separadamente, de modo a facilitar a memorização dos áudios. Assim, o jogo agrada tanto casuais quanto gamers que busquem um desafio.

------------------------------------------------------------------

Para ler a resenha completa, acesse:
http://falange.net/index.php/2016/06/23/falange-indie-2-circuits/

11421109.review:
Circuits is a music puzzle game where you match the sounds of individual tracks in the appropriate course of the "circuit." Ultimately, the game is a test is your aural detection and mimicry, and not much else.

While the game is titled Circuits, the gameplay relates to circuitry in only a superficial (using the symbol for ground, etc) manner - there is no actual relation to circuit design (ANDing or ORing the audio signals, for example) in order to create the music, which is somewhat disappointing. In each level, you are given a series of tiles each of which contain a single musical track. Along the progress bar of the "circuit", there are locations where you drop those tiles in order to match them to the given audio track. Sometimes you'll have to loop individual tracks or groups of tracks, and there are "switch"es where you choose one track over another, but in truth they only serve to make the levels easier, as the tiles are in fixed locations on them, which limits the areas those tiles can be used. 

Ultimately, this is a game of mimicry/memory. The last couple levels provide some degree of challenge within that constraint, but for the most part I didn't find the game particularly challenging/fun. The music itself was generally pleasant, and if there was something more to the game than "match what you hear" I would probably switch this to a recommend. But as is, I don't think most people would overly enjoy the game - if a game of matching audio tracks to one another sounds like fun, then by all means.

I'd recommend not splitting the layers in order to provide a higher level of difficulty - you'll probably get more out of it.

11384894.review:
June 4, 2015

I love the idea, but it's not for everyone, somewhat by design. Some people will struggle to distinguish different notes, and others will breeze through the game. It lacks the refinement to be a MUST experience, but the price is good for an interesting game. This is not a Portal or Braid, where the puzzles are solid yet beatable by everyone. An attentive ear is required to differenciate between some subtle notes. The music is fair, the best and worst tracks will stand out. All tracks are short and feel rushed, but I understand the difficulty in composing such tracks to fit on a screen. Some tracks seem to fit together oddly and sound similar, but I was picky about the details. The new track editor enables players to add more music and content.

The track editor does not simply take your music and break it into components, so don't expect Audiosurf puzzles here. I haven't messed with the Composer yet, and the smaller community means it's quiet so far. A game like this must be done manually, which is where some issues with poor note loops appear. I think that the amount of effort and data required for each track meant the devs used short collections of notes instead of actual songs. Hopefully some new songs appear, having improved quality and listener appeal along with length.

Gameplay is simple and solid, move notes around the screen. It feels a bit limited, like it was intended for touchscreen primarily. Keyboard shortcuts for loop numbers would be helpful. There is limited replayability, and tracks can be quite easy with all the optional hints and help. Some people recommend Musaic Box instead, but that is just a point-and-click puzzler with some public domain music, and doesn't let you compose the music in order. 

Circuits is doing something I've never seen before, and I praise it for that. It simply stumbled on this new ground, and could use more work. Still, the game is a nice experience and amazing deal at full price. I got the game under $1 USD, but I'd recommend Circuits to the musically-inclined at $5 USD.

11383995.review: A pretty unique music puzzle game where you have to re-create a track by placing sounds in their appropriate slots along a line.  The music I'd say is ambient/chill electronica and is well composed.  There are a few tricks like loops where you set the number of repeats, and switches that select between similar (but slightly different) sounds, but for the most part it's pretty straightforward.  It does get much harder in the last two puzzles, where you're denied the ability to split the melodies.  The only other game I've played like it is Auditorium, which is more free-form.  Not much replay value, but for $3 it's still well worth the time you'll get out of it.

Un aburrimiento de juego. Lastima, prometia, pero no. Es un asco.
Me arrepiento de comprarlo, y eso que me costó 0,74€

Yo lo diento, pero es que el juego es un asco. Y si, me he llegado lejos, concretamente a mas de la mitad del juego, ya que tenia la esperanza de que an algun momento se pusiese interesante. Pero NO, es un coñazo desde el principio hasta el final: no tiene ninguna emocion: no te pueden matar, si la cagas sencillamente te dice "uy, algo esta mal" y ala a corregirlo.
Tampoco hay tiempo, ni basicamente NADA que te motive a NADA.
Quiero decir que, si por lo menos te diesen puntos, se desbloqueasen cosas porque hayas resuelto un puzzle a la primera o yo que sé CUALQUIER COSA!! pero NO.

Si lo haces bien, tu recompensa es... pasa de nivel.
si lo haces mal, no pasa nada, sigue intentandolo hasta que te salga y una vez que lo tengas.... pasa de nivel.

Pero es que el siguiente nivel es LO MISMO que el anterior.
Uy si, perdona, te hacen mas pistas simultaneas... pero que mas da? si puedes desactivar cada pista y escucharlas todas por separado! Si por lo menos se te complicase la cosa en plan "ahora a ver si lo haces con todos los canales al mismo tiempo"
PERO NO

O si por lo menos te dejasen solo un numero determinado de intentos, al menos te motivarian UN POQUITO por hacerlo bien a la primera.... pero NO.

Este juego es tan entretenido como contar las moscas en la pared. Exactamente con el mismo nivel de aliciente.

Por otra parte, los sonidos estan bien, pero la musica es muchas veces tan BIZARRA que es directamente incoherente... Me recuerda a eso que llaman "musica clasica experimental" o "moderna", donde parece que hayan puesto a veintitres monos tocando instrumentos a destiempo y luego te dicen que si no te gusta es porque no entiendes el ARTE...

Vamos, que es un asco de juego.
Hey, desarrolladores, LO SIENTO, pero es que lo he intentado, DE VERDAD que lo he intentado, pero vuestro juego es para dormirse delante de la pantalla.
Lo que no llego a entender es... como es posible que, habiendo taaaantos juegos pendientes de evaluacion en Steam desde hace AÑOS, le hayan dado la luz verde a este!
claramente, nadie lo jugó. Vieron que estaba bien realizado y tal y dijeron "venga, pal saco"

PUES NO!

En serio, PERO QUE INTERES TIENE ESTE JUEGO???? ES QUE NO LO ENTIENDO!

Eso si, esta bien programado y los graficos son bonitos... lo cual es lo mismo que decir de una pelicula que tiene muy buena fotografia... por no decir que el argumento es una MI**DAAA !!!!!

Osea, que no lo compres. Mirate los videos que es lo unico que mola minimamente de este juego.

11300715.review:
I confess I was disapointed with Circuits. It's not that it's a bad game, not at all. The videos, images and reviews here, though, make it seem like a title with similar logic with Guitar Hero or Amplitude. It's a "music game" after all, how different can it be? A lot!

The subtle but huge difference is that in all those titles you take on the role of the "creator" or, at least, "fixer of broken" music: the music doesn't exist until you do your stuff and, hey presto, there it appears - and you feel like the best DJ in the world. Or guitarist. Or something.

Circuits is the polar oposite: they are "action" games, this is a puzzle game. Thus, the player is passive, and you don't "create music": you listen to a pre-existing song, again and again, and try to RE-create it by moving bits of it here and there.

As I've already written, that doesn't mean that it's a bad game - it's actually a great one. Just keep in mind that difference if you came here searching for your next Rez.

11284864.review: Circuits is a puzzle game that makes heavy use of sound. Your objective is to fit the various fragments of music given, lay them at the correct positions, to reproduce the desired sound. The trick is sometimes the notes are quite close, or you're given "red herring" fragments that are not needed, to throw you off, and sometimes there are subtle variations. As the difficulty increases, you'll be dealt with loops (infinite repeating refrains) and other pieces to assemble. The music is basically electronic trance / new age and are quite short and somewhat pleasing, and makes you appreciate music and layering of sound after sound to achieve the desired effect. And there are dozens of levels to solve. Circuits should appeal to puzzle solvers and any one with some interest in music.

Je l'ai acheté pour 0,74€ en solde. Autant vous dire que si ça avait été une énorme daube, j'aurais pu survivre sans trop de difficulté. Ca tombe bien, j'ai fait une super affaire.
Circuits est un jeu d'énigmes musicales, vous avez des morceaux de musique (voix, basse, guitare, piano etc) que vous devez replacer au bon endroit dans la piste. C'est tout simple, et pourtant, c'est excellent car l'interface est bien pensée, les musiques sont bien composées et surtout, variées (sauf du métal et pas de compagnie créole non plus). Si vous avez l'oreille sensible comme moi et que les "chansons" de Christophe Maé ou Maitre Gims vous brûlent les tympans, ne vous en faites pas, le compositeur est d'un autre niveau.

Bref : à 0,74€, indispensable. A 3€, si vous aimez les jeux de réflexion et la musique, ne réfléchissez pas plus longtemps : prenez-le.

11254609.review:
Nice misic-puzzle game. I didn't find it difficult, but very enjoyed the music. The aim is to listen and re-built the tracks.

Un buon puzzle-game musicale, in cui si deve riuscire a riprodurre una traccia audio dopo averla ascoltata.
Contrariamente ai (pochi) commenti negativi, non ho trovato i difetti citati. Il gioco ha solo le indicazioni necessarie per eseguire i puzzle iniziali (ma non c'è un menù con le spiegazioni), ed ha un buon senso di progressione della difficoltà tra i livelli.
Le tracce sono molto gradevoli.
Un puzzle diverso, stimolante per chi apprezza la musica e ha buon orecchio. Visto il prezzo è un must, qualcosa di diverso con cui dilettarsi.

11248997.review:
Circuits rappresenta per me il modello ottimo dal quale creare un indie game: idea alla base nuova, gameplay semplice ed immediato, nessun bug o glitch, livello di sfida sempre crescente ma bilanciato, comparto grafico minimale, niente splash screens o altre lecchinate di sorta verso il giocatore. Il gioco e il giocatore faccia a faccia, nient'altro, basta solo cliccare play.
Alla lunga non è difficile, però occorre un buon orecchio per andare avanti, in alcuni livelli ad esempio ci sono porzioni di pads la cui chiave differisce anche solo di un semitono, il che implica per il gioco l'utilizzo di cuffie con una buona amplificazione e con una banda passante senza "saltelli", o di un impianto che faccia risaltare queste differenze di tono.

Mi ha anche permesso di conoscere le creazioni del produttore della OST, David Garcia Diaz, è su Soundcloud per chi vuole ascoltare altre sue produzioni.

11247796.review:
Nice indie game, good to train your hearing for subtle differences. Plenty of hints given if you need them, too, so not one of those "I need a walkthrough!" kind of things, at all, that would just ruin a game like this (both needing it and being handed the solutions on a platter would just kill the fun). Just needs some persistence :) Good balance, guys! Keep it up!

I enjoyed the game for the most part - although I'm really not keen on the relatively heavy dubstep influence so many indie games have these days. Can we just get past this phase now, thanks?

Overall, I found it a little easy to go from start to finish, but that's because of my naturally very keen (absolute) hearing. I still heartily recommend it and would love to see more levels!

Присутствуют подсказки :поставить 1 выбранный музыкальный отрывок на правльное место;показать какие отрывки стоят неправильно.
Если у вас хороший музыкальный слух,и вы любите сложности,тогда эта игра для вас:)

11242868.review:
Only-Up-To-Level-5 Review

So hi guys. I've been playing this game for like 20 minutes but, guys, these things: This bro I know sees me playing this shit and he's like "tell me how it is" and I was all like "this is more mechanically static than i thought it would be but that makes sense seeing as music is generally of duration and such" so I cut it some slack yo, but I blurt out more nonsense like "it feels kind of like mastermind but with music... but maybe the second track just feels arbitrarily placed for some reason." You can move around samples and stuff and get a feel for different things (I liked on the fourth level where you had to pick one of two rhythms and one was more on beat while the other was somewhat staggered and it was neat to see how that affected the rest of the piece's pacing). Ultimately though you're restricted to the artistic act of music creation(???) because it is certainly reliant more on puzzle than on creativity, but it feels like it hits an odd spot in there, all up in the middle.

Sorry, I'm afraid to hit enter. Don't worry about it! Worry about this: that the game can do that is cool. it gives an element of learning music, because there is definitely an inherent feel to experimentation, but also that you can see some cadences, and they feel natural, and you're like "heck yeah guys. incomplete cadence? no way bruh".

The music seems to pretty much be in technological centered styles of music, and I guess - sure - it feels contemporary. 

Unfortunately I should probably point out that I make music? In my spare time? So it's like, I think a lot of people would find this chill and dare I fathom... *fun* and puzzling. But ultimately you're tied into what the music creator's framework is. You can experiment and just groove on it, and you can move around in the piece relatively quickly (though I would say interaction could feel less artificial, like, there's probably a better way to navigate than using a mouse on a linear scrollbar, and the two "play" mechanics feel awkward when they initiate similiar actions but within different contexts that aren't made readily apparent).

I would totally recommend this to people between "i play music occasionally" and "i like music and/or puzzle games that are relaxing". To me - personally! - it feels sorta like "i want to play something relaxing where I don't have to pay attention to creating but it feels like an awkwardly involved and unnecessarily restricted pantomime of musical sampling."

Though to that I end I give it a thumbs up because it let's me do all those things specifically, and it makes me want to jump on my own music setup, so birds?! Two of them?! am unsure of stone unit quantity but whatever babe that's just how i roll.

11233731.review:
Un juego genial, sencillo pero fantástico, quizás un poco corto, pero su precio también es reducido.

Circuits consigue hacer del ritmo un juego, su dificultad aumenta gradualmente y sus mecánicas son de fácil comprensión; el estilo visual y la música del juego te sumergen en el mundo del juego, lo que anima a superar nivel tras nivel sin descanso.

Sus puntos fuertes son: la originalidad, sus cuidadas mecánicas y la sensación de inmersión en un mundo dominado por el ritmo.

Sus puntos débiles son: la escasa duración del juego, unas 4 horas para 25 niveles (yo como mínimo hubiera creado 50 niveles), más modalidades de juego (la posibilidad de crear tus propios niveles y compartirlos con la comunidad sería algo interesante).

Valoración general: 8,5/10

11232833.review:
Voto Personale: Miglior Gioco 2014
Voto Classico: ★★★★☆

Questo piccolo capolavoro merita di essere acquistato, in sconto o meno.
25 tracce audio da ricomporre, livello di difficoltà crescente e ben proporzionato, gioco super rilassante, ottimo per prendersi una pausa da shooters e gameplay frenetici - OST incluso nella directory del gioco.

Personalmente lo sto giocando poco alla volta per non finire troppo in fretta; infatti, se proprio si vuol trovare una pecca a "Circuits", è la brevità di questo titolo. C'è però da mettersi nei panni degli sviluppatori che hanno budget e tempo limitato e nonostante tutto si sforzano di rispondere alle domande/pareri/suggerimenti degli utenti in tempo reale: colgo dunque l'occasione per ringraziare "Tentacle" per la simpatia e disponibilità. 

Thanks! We're eager to see the next episode!

11227165.review:
This game is fantastic by all means, however, it is still lacking a few things that I'd like ot see.  The game includes some fantastic loops and songs, but it's lacking a sandbox mode.  That's the biggest disappointment for me.  There are so many awesome samples being used, and I would LOVE to be able to remix and create my own songs using these components, but the feature is completely non-existent at this point.

There are also a lot of minor song components that are not included in the puzzle, but are played out automatically as the song progresses.  It would be nice to see an "Expert" difficulty in the future that forces players to add in ALL components of the song (echos/intros/outros).

Update: The developers are planning on releasing a "remix" mode in the near future that will allow us to create our own songs in the game.

11226992.review: Simple in concept, but very challenging and rewarding,Circuits is a puzzle game that requires careful listening to complete each level. The goal of Circuits : piece together the different parts of a song. Sounds easy, but maybe not.

11225138.review:
Ultimamente los juegos Indie me sorprenden cada vez más.

Juego que como si de un puzzle se tratara debes recomponer y ordenar las "piezas" musicales (ritmos, melodías, voces, fondos... etc) y conformar el puzzle de manera correcta.

MUY INTERESANTE, aunque me preocupa que a simple vista solo hay un numero reducido de niveles (25) no se si seran más, espero que sí (lo intentaré poner cuando lo averigüe). Y por el precio 0,74 centimos, no lo dejes escapar. Sinceramente lo recomiendo encarecidamente para todos aquellos que piensen que son buenos musicalmente, es un desafío cómodo y que te envuelve en una música maravillosa.

Realmente pienso que le puede gustar a todos los públicos puesto que puedes intentar hacerlo todo de golpe (como yo) o también puedes utilizar comodines o silenciar otros sonidos para centrarte bien en la composición que a veces son tan parecidas que aunque goces de buen oído y dotes musicales tendrás que recurrír a ellos.

¡FELICIDADES A LOS CREADORES!

11194988.review:
全実績解除時点でのレビューです。
前から気になっていたがセールをやっていたので購入。

お手本の曲を参考に音のピースを当てはめていくゲーム。こう書くとパズルゲームに聞こえるかもしれないが、どちらかと言うと音感ゲーム。最初の方は音のピースの数も少なくわかりやすいが、最後の方はかなりピースも増え複雑になってくる。
単音だけでなく和音を聴き分けるといったことも要求されるので、音感に全く自信のない人はあまり楽しめないかもしれない。ただ、絶対音感が必要というわけでもなく、相対音感と雰囲気で大体はなんとかなる。

ボリュームに関して。全部で25ステージ。私が全実績解除にかかった時間は5時間ほど。ゲームの価格を考慮すれば妥当といえるだろう。が、価格を考慮しない場合ちょっと物足りない感じもするのでDLCに期待したい。

音楽に興味がある、特に楽器を演奏したことがあるといった人にはおすすめできるが、ただパズルゲームをやりたいという人は他のゲームをあたったほうがいいかもしれない。どういうゲームか理解した上での購入なら損はしないだろう。

11194364.review:
The simplicity of the game design has caught my attention. 

So far, the puzzle games I came across require your eyes and brain but this one requires 2 additional and most important components which are your ears. You have to be a very careful listener and patient player when playing Circuits. The feeling you get after completing a round of placing music segments in its correct order is purely satisfying. 

I recommend it if you want to challenge your listening ability and patience. Of course,it's highly recommended for people who's searching for a puzzle game relating to music at a reasonable price. 

P.S. The OST is downloaded as well in your SteamApps folder when you download Circuits. Soooo... free Circuits Soundtrack!

11192324.review:
게임성8/10
확실히 시간을 보내기에는 좋은 게임이고, 플레이 방법도 간단하지만, 어딘가 이 소재를 사용했기에 따른 확실한 부족한 점이 보이는 부분이 있었다.

그래픽10/10
조잡하지 않은 간단한 그래픽은 게임에 대한 몰입도를 더욱 높여준다. 더 이상의 설명은 생략한다.

사운드10/10
뉴에이지풍 사운드는 그 자체로 앨범이 나오면 기꺼이 지를 수 있을 정도의 퀄리티의 음악을 들려 준다. 내가 음악을 듣고 있는건지 게임을 하는 건지 헷갈릴 정도로.

효율10/10
나 같은 경우는 많이 할인할 때 샀는데, 지금 확실히 후회하지 않고 재밌게 플레이하고 있다. 

총평 : 다 필요없고 본격 "우리의 소리를 찾아서" 게임... 게임을 진행할수록 소리에 집착하는 자신을 보게 된다...

11189452.review:
Circuits is a simon says game that relies on auditory memory rather than visual. You don't have to be a musician to play the game, nor will you become a musician if you do play the game. The concept is fantastic, the sound is, quite literally, amazing. (So often these days indie games have better music than AAA games). However most adults will likely get bored by level 10. I myself am writing this review after closing the game at level 11, and most likely won't play it again. 

If that is the case, why do I recommend this game? Children. Just like how Portal is used in school programs, I think this game concept definitely have a place in school as well. It's clean (at least up until level 11). An adult most likely will not take anything away from this game, but a developing young one will definitely develope auditory recognition which could help with anything from future music interests or even learning the characteristics of a foreign language later. 

So it's not for me, but I still recommend it. And currently at $0.74 USD, why not?

11186500.review:
[h1]Original musical puzzlegame[/h1]

This is an extremely original game, very well executed and polished. It's all about listening carefully to short musical examples (which are quite well made actually) and trying to re-compose them. To this purpose you get several original tools: you can listen to the music layer-by-layer (for example, strings only, or bass only), and you get snippets of music which you can place in their appropriate place on the timeline.
Could sound very demanding and even baffling, but it's very well executed, and the difficulty level goes very slowly up. Still, you need good ears - the ability to recognize different pitches and rhythms, at the very least.
So this is probably not a game for just everybody, but for those who want a game with some artistic claims, and want to enjoy playing around with music, this is a real treat. And yes, the graphics are very good: functional, but oh so artistic. Playing a game like this, I realized once more that games really are art, sometimes (and more and more often with all these indie-talents of recent years).

Gameplay: 24/30 (it's very satisfying to finish a new level)
Graphics: 14/20 (functional, static, but oh so beautiful)
Sound: 9/10 (best enjoyed with good headphones!)
Replayability: 12/20 (it's quite a challenge to complete the levels, but once done, it's done)
Stability: 18/20

Overall: 77/100

11161246.review:
7/10/2014
Circuits is a fantastic little listening puzzle game (aka aural skills game).  After the fact that this is a puzzle game relying on your listening skills (extremely rare) and memory, the soundscapes are the main feature of this game.  Personally, I love them.  They create a sense of a vast space that really make this a memorable experience. I only wish there were longer puzzles and more music!

Interface is simple and intuitive.  Only improvement I could see here is having a pause button in addition to a stop button in the playthrough mode (the devs might have intentionally left out to make the game slightly harder too), but since you can scroll anywhere instantly it doesn't really matter.

I hope in the future there is workshop support or some kind of user-level-generation as this game is begging for both more content and more twists/different music/sound styles. 

Took me about 4 hours to complete the game and all achievements without using any hints or the layer isolation mode.  If you don't have any ear training under your belt then it will take you longer  (mainly for the golden ear achievement)... or of course if you have an exceptional ear and memory then shorter.

Thanks for the great game, Tentacle devs!

11161139.review:
Still playing it, but for the price I paid, I'd say the game is worth it.  There are a few small critiques, but otherwise, it's everything I expected it to be, and I would caution people to watch the videos before purchasing so you know what you're paying for, since not realizing what they were buying seems to be a common theme among the naysayer reviewers.

Firstly, I love most of the music.  I'm not a huge synthesizer/autotune fan, so for those levels I just kind of powered through. But otherwise I really enjoyed it.  It was very relaxing and a nice exercise in listening.

I think having an option to go to the Level Menu from the Pause Menu would help a lot.  It would make going back and looking for a particular level much easier.

There was one level that sounded like it was misaligned? Level 6 "My voice has no soul" I think.  I don't know if that's the style of music, but it almost grated on my ears how the piano parts and the autotune/synth voice was just barely not in sync (or at least sounded that way to me).

I think there could probably be some improvements in the design to make it more "puzzley" and heighten the "risk vs reward" factor, like not making the entire soundtrack with all the sounds available to listen to while you try to solve it (aka only letting the player access the parts so that the final piece is revealed at the end) which will trim down on the complaints about having to listen to a track over and over and getting nothing for their time.  You could also split it into two modes so you have one version of the track that only lets you listen to the individual parts in order to complete the puzzle, and another version that only has all the tracks together, which will require the user to listen much more closely and separate sounds in their brain.  This second type of puzzle, since the music itself is no longer a reward for completing the puzzle, could have a different kind of reward, like unlocking other puzzles, or unlocking a piece of a code that will allow the player to access a compilation musical soundtrack of the game's music and the final puzzle is actually the player arranging the code pieces to actually unlock it.  Anyway, it's an idea, take it or leave it.

I think it would be a lot of fun if there was a part of the game that allowed players to create their own circuit puzzles and share them (lots of possibilities if you connect to something like the Steam Workshop).

All in all, the game has a lot of potential, and I'd like to see it go places and evolve, but as is, it has a more than fair price and is fun on its own.  Keep up the great work!

11148169.review:
As a musician, I was immediately intrigued by this game.  I thought I would check it out for a few minutes after adding it to my library today, but instead ended up spending the entire evening playing through it.  Needless to say, my expectations were exceeded on all accounts.

Circuits is an audio puzzle game.  Perhaps not the first in this genre but certainly the best I have ever experienced.  The art design is elegantly simple and the music is amazing.  Good headphones are definitely a plus as the sound is absolutely central to the experience.

There are currently only 25 levels to the game, and even playing without using any hints or layers options, it still took me a few good hours to get through them all.  The game is as challenging as you’d like it to be.  Even if you are not musically inclined, I would still urge you to give this game a try.  The gameplay is simple, and the optional hints and layers make it accessible for everyone.  The music alone is easily worth the price.

Digital Tentacle is the small indie company that created Circuits.  Not only did they produce a beautifully fun and awesome game, but they are very active on the forums and care a great deal about their product and their fans.  They’ve even added the full soundtrack to the game file for everyone to enjoy, completely free of charge.  I know this has nothing to do with the game (which is already awesome in its own right) but I am very impressed by their commitment and humbleness.  

Circuits is ear training at its best.  Even at the full price, the game is a steal.  Go ahead and pick it up today.  I’m certain you will not regret it.

特别棒的音乐游戏，上手之后直接上瘾。打算这几天把它打通了，蛮好玩的。游戏模式是把音乐组合起来，得到一整段音乐，只是有顺序和重复次数的问题。游戏内带有提示系统和帮助系统，应该说还是比较人性化的一款游戏。
不过成就系统十分坑，估计要入全成就需要投入很多，甚至要背音乐了……没有重复测试关卡，不知道音盘的位置会不会变动。人声和鼓点感觉不好听，处理的痕迹太明显了。
如果你是个音乐人，熟悉MIDI的话，这个游戏给你的体验将是完全不一样的，这种简明的分轨和排序会把你代入一个播放器的角度——可能我这么说不太好理解——就是仿佛你自己就是一台播放器，你在解读自己的音乐。总归，很不错的游戏，希望可以推出更多音乐。

11140792.review:
Circuits ist ein simples Spiel, dessen Erfolgsrezept im Soundtrack liegt: Kein Level ist wie das nächste, Abwechslung ist allein schon durch die verschiedenen Lieder jedes Levels gegeben!
Das Spiel baut auf Geduld und Ruhe auf und belohnt die, die zuhören können. Dabei muss man nicht unbedingt ein musikalisches Genie sein, um die einzelnen Lieder aufzubauen. Wichtig ist vor allem, sich auf Kleinigkeiten konzentrieren zu können und die kleinen Musikschnipsel vergleichen zu können, denn manchmal unterscheiden sich zwei verschiedene Liedteile nur in einer einzigen Note!
Die Idee hinter Circuits ist eine, die man so noch nie richtig in einem Spiel gesehen hat, und gerade das macht es auch so interessant. Gepaart mit dem Soundtrack und der angenehmen Umsetzung ist das Spiel definitiv eine Kaufempfehlung.

Ich persönlich hätte mir mehr Level gewünscht, da der Schwierigkeitsgrad eher an die breite Masse angepasst ist, und man relativ zügig die Level durcharbeiten kann (wenn man denn will), dennoch hatte ich zu keinem Zeitpunkt das Gefühl, dass Circuits zu einfach war (höchstens eben zu kurz).

Und ganz ehrlich: Allein für den wunderschönen Soundtrack lohnt sich das Geld.

11134690.review:
Habe das Spiel gestern im Angebot gesehen und spontan gekauft. Heute habe ich es durchgespielt... macht sehr viel Spaß.

Das Spielkonzept ist einfach und genial: Setzte ein vorgegebenes Musikstück aus seinen Einzelteilen zusammen. Nachdem man sich reingehört hat (der Musikstil ist etwas gewöhnungsbedürftig), versucht man Schnipsel anzuhören und in die passenden Löcher zu setzten - die Steuerung ist intuitiv und wird im Laufe des Spiels erklärt. Man kann sich sowohl die vorgegebene Musik als auch die Schnipsel und das, was man schon zusammengesetzt hat, beliebig oft wiederholen, und es gibt kein Zeitlimit. Man kann sich ganz auf die kleinen Unterschiede konzentrieren, die die kleinen Meldoieteile untereinander haben - mal unterschiedliche Instrumente, mal leichte Abweichungen in der Melodie. Wenn man denkt, dass man alles geschafft hat, lässt man seine Zusammensetzung einmal durchspielen, und das Spiel sagt am Ende, ob das richtig war. Falls man nicht mehr weiter weiß, gibt es auch kleine Hilfen, z.B. dass man nur eine Stimme statt allen hört.

Das Spiel macht Spaß, und ich hätte vermutlich unendlich so weiter machen können. Zum Ende hin werden die Level recht anspruchsvoll, aber es ist machbar. Teilweise passte die Musik nicht ganz (leichte Taktverschiebungen auch in der Soll-Variante oder knapp falsche Töne), aber solche Kleinigkeiten machen ein Indie-Spiel ja liebenswert :-)

11132281.review:
Ziel des Spiels ist es ein vorgegebenes Musikstück mit den richtigen Instrumenten, Sounds und Backround usw nachzuspielen. Dazu platziert man die entsprechenden Schnipsel auf der Playleiste, drückt dann auf play und hofft das man richtig zugehört hat. Klingt simpel, ist es auch. Aber wie sagt man so schön, gerade die einfachsten Dinge sind am Besten. Und so ist es auch hier. Schon nach kurzer Zeit ist man wegen dem chilligen Ambient-und Trancesound dermaßen Tiefenentspannt und konzentriert auf die einzelnen Sounds, dass man anfängt rum zu experimentieren, auch wenn es mal nicht dem Originaltrack entspricht. Mit zunehmenden Level werden die Tracks immer anspruchsvoller und umfangreicher. Damit man den Überblick behält kann man einzelne Soundgruppen ausblenden um sich z.B. erstmal nur den Backround zu widmen. Später kommen dann noch so neckische Dinge wie Loops und Wegeschalter hinzu, was die ganze Sache dann nochmal kniffeliger macht. Mit 25 Leveln ist es zwar nicht gerade sehr umfangreich, aber die Zeit die man mit Circuits verbringt lohnt sich definitiv, vorrausgesetzt man verfügt über ein einigermaßen intaktes musikalisches Gehör. Einzig eine Art "create"-Modus vermisst man um eigene Minitracks zu kreieren.
Kaufempfehlung!

11101805.review:
Circuits is essentially a music puzzle game, where you get to reconstruct melodies by putting little sound hubs in their right positions to build a track. The game mechanic is based on you listening to certain melodies and then identiying the proper sounds and putting them in the right order. Note that you will probably have to listen to some parts repeatedly to get them right, since it is something not everyone has the patience for.

The difficulty is generally not high, except towards the end (levels 24-25). You can, however, choose to *not* break up the music into layers in the previous levels, so it will be harder for you to distinguish the different sounds playing at the same time. The game is a tad short, I finished it in roughly 4 hours, but that can vary depending on the person. However, the developers have promised more levels in the near future, so this might change.

Overall, I would say that circuits is worth your time.  It is simple, yet elegant and relaxing if you are generally musically inclined. It is hard to comment beyond personal preferences for this type of game, since I feel it is mostly a matter of taste, so if you think what I have mentioned so far is something you will like, you will probably enjoy this game as I have.

В особенности в последних двух-трёх. Уровней немного, но по мне в самый раз, рекомендую проходить порционно. Как и сказано в игре лучше воспринимается в наушниках.

Very nice and clean. You will love it if you are a musician but you'll hate it if you have absolutely no musical ear (as the whole gameplay is based on that). The only annoying thing is the fact that you play only with the mouse. There is two play modes (one for the music you have to reconstruct and one for what you have reconstructed yet) so you always have to move the cursor and click on play buttons and layers buttons that are apart from each other. With such a simple gameplay, it would have been easy to add keyboard shortcuts (spacebar?) for play modes, and 1,2,3,4 keys for layers. That's the only tiny thing missing from this game.

Gameplay tip :
Reconstruct each songs layer by layer before listening to the whole thing, it gaved me more eargasms to discover the song after reconstructing it. It feels more like you've made it instead of just copying it.

10990174.review:
I wanted to like this game.

If the music was better, it might have been worth it. It wasn't bad, but it wasn't good enough to justify the rest of the game.

If the puzzles had been more varied, it might have been worth it. There are a couple of different gameplay elements, but they don't provide any real variety.

If the puzzles had been more difficult and complex, it might have been worth it. As it was, they felt less like a challenge and more like an exercise in tedium. Instead of getting difficult, they just got longer. 

The last two puzzles were the most interesting, since the game forces you to figure things out by listening to all of the song layers at once. You have to listen very closely to pick out the parts of the song that are relevant to the pieces you're trying to place. Unfortunately, even here, it became frustrating, simply because some of the sounds were so completely masked by the other sounds that it felt like I had no choice but to guess.

The idea is very clever! I like the concept of using sound this way. It's just the execution that felt unsatisfying. More meta-modifiers like the loops and repetitions and better use of the control switches so they required more thought about the overall structure of the song rather than just the next sound clip would have helped immensely.

10740543.review:
По ощущениям похожа на сканворд с последней страницы в бесплатной газете. Это простенькая головоломка, языком которой являются семплы, нет ни целостности музыкальных композиций (услышав первые треки вы поймёте что к ним абсурдно применять такие понятия), ни комфорта от прокручивания семплов (а вы будете обязаны слушать даже неприятные семплы, потому что ключеваые для разгадки различия заключаются в синкопе или диезе в середине семпла), ни чувства творчества которое дарит любой семплер.

Это детская головоломка, стиля "подбери фигурку попадающую в пазик", от не_музыкантов для не_слушателей.
Потомучто задачи буквально подбери из двух предложеных семплов тот где синкопа стоит как в услышаном примере, и ладнобы но неудобный плеер примеров вынуждает тратить лишнее время - вы никогда не сможете ткнуть в место где начинается нужны семпл.

Денег своих игра не стоит, потому-что как голомка она ничтожна, а как игра с музыкой музыки в себе не содержит, она даже к ушам слушателя неуважительно относится, что по моему обязательно даже для далеко не музыкальных игр (и ими выполняется на отлично): отдельные семплы звучат громче чем весь трек, что ощутимо бьёт по ушам, особенно аудиалам, на кого по идее и ориентированны игры с музыкой. Это механически скиданные в кучу семплы, по принципу взаиморазличия, а не эстетического сочетания.

Ну и для меня лично, это очередное подтверждение что игры нельзя покупать до того как игру ты попробовал. Или что индустрии нужен работающий механизм возврата денег за непонравившийся проект.

10725215.review:
This game requires you to listen to some soundtracks and reconstruct them from individual parts. You can separate the soundtrack into individual layers, which makes it easy to listen and compare the music pieces and find the right place for each one... but that's not even a challenge, and I think there is no point in playing the game like this.

But if you have a good musical ear (and headphones), you can choose not to use layers (there is an achievement for that), so you can only listen to the complete unmodified track, with up to 3 "instruments" playing at the same time. And that makes things interesting, in some cases nearly impossible. But that's when hints come into play! You just need to get things mostly right and then you may use hints to logically deduce the rest, which is also quite fun.
Oh, and if you want more, then you can play with layers but without hints (which is another achievement), so there's some replayability.

In conclusion, Circuits is an interesting game, but I wouldn't recommend it to most people.

★★★★★★☆☆☆☆

10621757.review:
A couple months ago I saw this game's title on the front page and was like, "Huh, what is this?" After reading the decription, I was pleasantly surprised. Being a musically-inclined individual, the idea of a replicate-the-song musical puzzler has always interested me. I was also very shocked by the price. I mean, less than five dollars for 25 levels? Sign me right up!

The game has no story. It's an abstract puzzle-solving game where you must listen to a song and try to recreate it with the musical nodes you are given. As you progress, different mechanics will be added including looping individual nodes, looping groups of nodes, and switches which allow you to chose between several pre-placed nodes. Each level is comprised of lines and symbols similar to those you'd find on a circuit diagram, hence the game's name. Surprisingly enough, the game has quite an atmosphere, with the soundtrack being an amalgam of orchestral (strings, piano, brass, and even a flute solo in one level) and electronic drums and synthesizers. Some songs even have vocal parts, but in most cases they are heavily-processed beyond recognition. The music certainly creates an eerie mishmash of the organic and the cybernetic. Despite this stark contrast, nothing feels out of place. It all fits together remarkably well. Not only that, but the soundtrack comes free with purchase of the game. I mean come on! You'll pay less for this entire game than you will for other games' soundtracks by themselves. That's a steal in my book.

Now, I admit the game is not for everyone for obvious reasons. Of course, you don't need to know the exact difference between a C and a C#, but there are some points in the game where your choices sound remarkably similar. I remember one particular scenario where you had to select from five nodes using a switch. They were all sustained string chords and all had the same pitch. The only difference between them was the timbre, or "tone quality/brightness." These switchers seem to be a stumbling block for a lot of people and I can understand why. The game does offer two types of hints--one which places a node in its correct position and another which marks incorrectly-placed nodes--along with a "layer system" where you can separate the track to only play the red, yellow, or purple-colored nodes, and while I never had to use them, I thank the developers for including such a feature.

The developers have promised more levels and possibly more mechanics in the future and I can't wait to see what they come up with. Overall this game is pretty good for one I wouldn't have even known existed had I not been browsing Steam at the right time. This game gets 6 S's out of 7. Highly recommended.

身為一個學習音樂多年的音樂人和音樂愛好者，這款真可完全說是"我的遊戲"啊XD
拜過去多年的音樂培育環境所賜，我擁有平時沒甚麼用處的絕對音感和良好的節奏感，但玩這款遊戲時就完全變成了一種享受；因為房間裡就擺著一台電子鋼琴在我電腦邊，所以甚至會邊聽邊把旋律複製下來，不少片段都富有原創性和啟發性，讓我自己本身拿手的現代音樂風格又多了一些靈感，是款極富趣味、氣氛輕鬆以及充滿創造力的作品。

這款遊戲的目的在於把聽過的旋律用各種元素重組，以完整重現音樂的片段。基本有弦樂、Bass、打擊樂、鋼琴和人歌聲等，後面的關卡會添加更多元素，例如重複次數和迴圈設定的加入，讓遊戲更有了耐玩度。各關卡音樂本身可以分層聽，把不同的樂器分開對聽覺不那麼敏銳的人會是比較容易的開始，不過我個人還是喜歡不分層聽，感覺比較有挑戰性XD

不只要求記憶性，良好的音高音感、節奏感、音色辨識能力都是能夠在這款音樂遊戲中學習培養到的。就算對音樂沒太多概念也能單純享受好音樂，強烈推薦給也喜歡音樂的朋友，這款前所未見的音樂藝術品絕對能讓你獲益良多。

順帶一提，我玩到目前的關卡幾乎都是不拆解聽一遍就能全部放對，成就感破表，總感覺有點作弊啊XD

Circuits
[9/10]

10405904.review:
This is little indie gem for people who enjoy fiddling with music or would like to test their musical ear. It's visually simple but beautiful nonetheless and the concept and gameplay are well executed. The controls, while occasionally fiddly and not always intuitive, are simple enough once you get used to them. New elements are introduced at a good pace, keeping the game fresh. I didn't love all the musical pieces as such, but there's no accounting for taste, and they were all well done and interesting to listen to. The actual puzzles themselves progressed nicely in difficulty with the occasional easier respite in between. I often felt like sharing a joke with the devs, when some of the differences demanded you listen really closely for that half a beat or that one note to tell them apart - and that's always a good sign in puzzlers.

The only small annoyance were the last two puzzles. My issue with them has little to do with the difficulty (the last two SHOULD be difficult) and more to do with what is required of you. When you can't separate the tracks and some of the tracks are so deep in the mix that both I and my musician partner basically had to either guess or revert to hints, something isn't right. My headphones are of medium quality, but definitely not the worse, and I did enjoy solving some previous puzzles without splitting the tracks, so those two felt disporportionately hard and left a somewhat bitter note at the end. Yes, that was a bad pun. ;)

But all in all it's a great, interesting, original, fun little game and very cheaply priced for the amount of gameplay it offers. Personally I had a fantastic time with it and I would be willing to pay for dlc with extra levels. If you like playing around with music, this is one of the best music based puzzle games I've played so far and you really can't beat the price.

Ключевое слово - "музыку". Во первых я очень не люблю все музыкальные игры, так как я их не понимаю: либо игровой процесс там не привязан к музыке никаким образом (audiosurf, beat hazzard) и тогда остаётся просто тем же самым "казуальным", но в "маркетинговой" обёртке, либо он привязан, и в таком случае игра просто вне пределов моего понимания.

Проблема в том, что я даже не знаю куда отнести эту игру: с одной стороны это обычная мозаика, и соответственно решить её можно перебором, с другой - она явно требует познания в сотворении музыки (или типа того) для правильного решения.

И снова ключевое слово "музыка". Вместо музыки здесь какое-то невозможно однообразное эмбиент-дерьмо, которое я не различаю ни внутри головоломки, ни между уровнями, ни во всём жанре целиком. Для меня это такой же статический шум как на кассетах для релаксации: шум моря, щебетание птиц, шелест листвы, потрескивание костра, эротические звуки батхёрта.

10328759.review:
TL;DR - it's good, definitely worth the money for the amount of time you'll put in, especially for the later puzzles.

I got this game at a discounted price, but it's definitely worth the full cost of three whole dollars. It took me about 4 hours to get through all 25 puzzles (and I hear talk of DLC or updates on the way, including a song by the person who did super hexagon's soundtrack), plus another hour to get all of the remaining achievements, so compared to a $6 movie for 3 hours of entertainment, or a $60 game for 40-50 hours of play, $3 for 5 hours is a good deal.

Circuits is a musical puzzler game where you have to arrange blocks of music together to match the desired music. It has a very intuitive layout and the mechanics are all very easy to understand, with each new feature being introduced individually so you aren't overwhelmed with everything immediately.

It is a bit short, but with the achievements (especially golden ear) there's enough incentive to replay the levels, and like I said above, there's supposed to be some new levels and music coming soon.

Overall, this is a neat little game with an interesting concept that I would recommend you pick up if you've got some time to kill and don't mind breaking your bank; I know not everyone can afford not to have their morning cup of coffee.

10265438.review:
Im Grunde geht es um eine Melodie, die man richtig nachspielen muß. Es gibt verschiedene Punkte an denen jeweils ein neues Teilstück der Musik einsetzt. Man hat diese Teilstücke und muß sie nun den jeweiligen Punkten zuweisen. Als Hilfe hat man ein Mini-Mischpult, an dem man die in verschiedenen Farben getrennten Stücke abhören kann (z.B. nur gelbe/rote usw.).

Ich mag das Spiel. Allerdings ist es absolut nichts für *mal eben spielen*. Dafür ist es viel zu schwer. Es erfordert nicht nur ein sehr gutes Gehör, sondern auch noch viel Erinnerungsvermögen um sich an den kleinen Unterschied von "Ping" und Piing" zu erinnern. Und da man nicht eben so nur den Unterschied zwischen 2 Punkten hören kann (ohne den teilweise recht großen Rest ebenfalls mitzuhören) kann es schon etwas frustriend werden.

10244118.review: It's an interesting concept - build songs by placing sections into a circuit flow chart. It's basically a more involved version of Simon, but it works really well, and was surprisingly challenging, especially in the later levels. There are multiple tracks, and some pieces repeat (or some piece groups repeat), and sometimes you have to choose which of multiple tracks is the right one. There are only 25 levels, and a few too many of the early ones are tutorial-focused, so it only took me a little over 2 hours to play through it, but I enjoyed all of it. If you like light electronica, or symphonic (and a couple that sounded a bit like Tron Legacy's Soundtrack), the music will work for you too. I love most every music-based game I play, and this is a very different and unique one. I only wish there were more levels, or an editor where you could chain loops up and build your own songs.

10241992.review: This game is a gem for sure.  It's true, music games hold a special place in my head, in between the headphones which this game even recommends that you use.  Some use music in novel ways that go with the beat and flow.  This one goes in a unique way as well by allowing you to effectively build up music by relying on your own ability not to follow a tempo so much as to hear the notes, keys, etc. and decide where they go.  And you can efficitely create your own piece (there are 25 levels) but to progress you must match up the "correct" circuit layout.  It's extremely organic and very user based as you can turn on and off the different layers of sounds in each level to deal with one set at a time.  If you like music you really should get this game.  At the moment it's on the latest indiegala bundle, but it's well worth it's modest normal price for sure.

10108190.review:
To put it simply: this is a somewhat interesting tech demo, but it is not a puzzle game.

A puzzle game should make you feel awesome after solving a level. All I'm feeling after a dozen levels of Circuits is the urge to rant about game design.

Listening to the same samples over and over and over again to figure out where to place them is boring. Activation of nodes is entirely linear (at least so far) and there is nothing clever you can do beyond just grinding each level out. Gameplay is often slow, and the controls feel awkward. Level transitions goes on too long and are unskippable. There's a speed up feature to skip playing the entire song once you have a solution but it is still too slow.

And, to top it off, I personally found the samples and songs almost grating to my ears.

Very good game. This mix re-composing a short track while enjoying listening to music at the same time. I used to make music with FL Studio and I can tell that this game makes use of the music theory by splitting the different instruments (melody, pad, voice, drums etc..) Very enjoyable. I just hope there will be more music genres such like trance progressive.
I'm currently on level 13 out of 25 and I found them pretty easy so far. The tracks are short and not that hard. Perhaps more complicated song with more instruments and effect could make this game a little bit harder.

10047627.review:
After watching the trailer, you probably believe that you have to construct the whole [i]circuit[/i] yourself. However, it is not like that; the gameplay is quite simple, you just place different samples in the already constructed circuit. The game consists of 25 levels with increasing difficulty. In each level, you will be played a song which you have to construct by placing samples/beats in its proper spot. Unless you have very precise hearing, you will end up rewinding song multiple times and trying different combinations. It is not so much of a puzzler, because you do not have to think but hear. 

Even though, the gamplay is not that diverse, I did enjoy the tracks and playing around with the differnt combinations. Anyone who likes music games might just enjoy this game, but do not expect anything special. Anyone with not so good sense of hearing will find this game frustrating. Hopefully, in future they add the ability for you to construct the whole [i]circuit[/i] and make your own songs (maybe even a workshop where you can share your songs for others to solve). 

[u]Bottom Line[/u]
Anyone who doesn't enjoy [i]point and click[/i] games, should not buy it as you will get bored very soon. If you do not expect more than few hours of gameplay or replayability, and are interested in music games and by the concept; then you should get it.

9961378.review:
Zum Anfang schon mal vorweg: Man muss ein gutes Gehör für dieses Spiel haben. Man sollte in der Lage sein, einzelne Instrumente aus einem Orchester herauszuhören.
Außerdem sollte man sich auf ein paar Ecken und Kanten im Spiel gefasst machen. Vor allem in der zweiten Hälfte des Spiels wird es richtig schwer. Das schreckt einige Leute ab.

[b]Warum empfehle ich trotzdem dieses Spiel?[/b]

[b][u]Ich kenne kein anderes Spiel wie dieses.[/u][/b]
Es ist nicht so abstrakt wie andere Rätsel-Spiele. Man muss sich die Musik anhören, um die Lösung zu finden.
Es ist wie ein klassisches Puzzle, wo man aus den Teilen ein Bild zusammensetzt. Nur setzt man hier kein Bild, sondern ein Lied zusammen.

[b][u]Die Atmosphäre spricht an.[/u][/b]
Die Spielmechanik ist schnell erlernt. Die Bedienung ist einfach. Die Lieder sind stimmig. Es lenkt nichts vom Puzzle ab.
Man denkt nur noch über die Lösung nach. Nach einiger Zeit verliert man sich in die Musik. Man hört ganz genau hin und entdeckt die zahlreichen Facetten des Stückes.

[b][u]Es ist fair.[/u][/b]
Man bekommt, was man braucht, um die Puzzles zu lösen. Man kann es immer wieder probieren. Es gibt ein paar Hinweise, wenn man sie möchte. Sollte man ein Level vorerst nicht schaffen, kann man es sofort überspringen. Alles ohne Nachteile im Spiel.
Natürlich gibt es einige schwerere Stellen, aber das Spiel versucht niemals, einen auszutricksen. Die Unterschiede der Teile sind hörbar.

[b][u]Es fördert das Gehör.[/u][/b]
Das eigene Gehör verbessert sich bei jedem Level. Man spürt, wie man die Töne immer besser heraushört.
Wenn man das Spiel geschafft hat, kann man es nochmal ohne Hilfen versuchen. Wenn man das auch schafft, hat man das Gehör schon sehr geschärft. Der Unterschied zwischen vor und nach dem Spiel ist riesig.

Alles in allem bietet das Spiel ein einmaliges Erlebnis. Es bleibt im Gedächtnis hängen. Das eigene Gehör verbessert sich. Das ist auch außerhalb des Spiels nützlich.
Die Entwickler versprechen Verbesserungen und neue kostenlose Inhalte. Somit hat man auch später Spaß mit diesem Spiel.

9932784.review:
This is a really rather well-done music puzzle game asking players to select the correct samples in order to complete the piece of music.  It's fairly simple, with some added twists such as loops, switches, and repetitions, but very addictive.  The puzzles are interesting and increase in difficulty, but the game overall is rather short (the 25 levels should really only take you a few hours to complete).  

The music included is atmospheric and relaxing, and will largely be what hinges on your appreciation of the game.  If you enjoy chillstep, you'll be sucked into the game, if not, you might find it grating (and possibly repetitive, even though the game really isn't).  Which to me leads to the only real downside of the game.  If it had a sandbox mode, an editor, or the ability to incorporate your own music into the game, it would be perfect.  As it stands, it's still a solid music puzzle game, but it's dependent on whether you enjoy the music already presented in the game.

9891455.review: Circuits is the kind of puzzle game I'd like to see more of. It's essentially a very simple music sequencer, 25 short pieces of music (chillstep, ambient) with a "stem" that acts as a timeline. You're given a handful of nodes, each containing short musical phrases or snippets of percussion, and you have to put them on the correct placeholders along the stem. You can play the entire piece of music and drag the timeline slider to any point, so it's pretty easy at first to build the song. Later levels get a bit more difficult, with subtle chord differences or slight variations in note timing, and nodes or sequences of nodes that must be allocated a certain amount of repeats, but unless you're tone deaf it's not too difficult. It's a neat concept, the music is worth a listen (the OST is included), and it's probably a fun way of learning the very basics of song composition. The developer has promised some harder levels in the future, as the basic game will take you about 2-3 hours to finish.

9888151.review:
I'm not a connoisseur of music.  I mostly listen to soundtracks, using them as an auditory trigger to try and relive the resonant moments that I felt when watching a movie or playing a video game.  Sometimes I close my eyes and try to unravel the music.  I don't claim to do so with any expertise; but there are minor revelations, and then I marvel at the composer's expertise and imagination at  constructing the end result.

Circuits is a puzzle game that peels the curtain back a bit further.  The concept is simple: you are given auditory snippets which you must arrange in the correct manner in order to reproduce a song.  There are up to three layers in a song, and (prior to the last two levels) the game allows you to listen to each layer individually - a fascinating insight into the mind of a composer.

There are additional puzzle elements - switches, loops, extraneous sound bites - but Circuits introduces each complication gently, and removes them before they overstay their welcome.  This restraint in puzzle design helps ensure that the experience never grows stale.

---- Pbbt ----

Once upon a time there was a boy who could only make one sound.  No matter what he did - how he shaped his lips or moved his tongue or pressed air through his teeth - that single sound was the only one that would ever emerge.  Which sound was this?  Stick your tongue between your lips, press down, and blow.  Yep, that's the one.

Still, this was not the worst affliction in the world, or so the boy's parents told themselves.  They enrolled the boy in a school for the deaf, where he learned to use his hands to sign his thoughts to others.  It was a hardship of course, but one that the human race at large understood and even sympathized with.  And so the boy grew up into a man who did not dread the greater world.  Instead he faced it with a straight back, a strong heart, and a grin on his face.

Until the fateful day when he heard the last movement of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G9EJE1ad36Q](link)[/url].  In his mind the voices wove a glittering fabric, rising and falling strands of color and exaltation that created a single Ode to Joy.  The man listened to Beethoven's masterpiece again, and then again, and then again and again, and there was a moment when he realized that he was both lost and in love, and perhaps the two were not so different?  Yes: the man was both lost and in love, and not knowing where he was, there was nowhere else he would rather be.

That day a path was created for the man, clear and straight and true.  He would become a singer.  Not a great one, of course - the man was not delusional - but perhaps if he studied and trained enough, he would be rewarded with a small place in a great choir.  And then one day his voice would be added to the song he adored.

It was not to be.

I will spare you the details of the man's tragedy, give you but a clouded view of the moment when the man realized that his body had betrayed him from birth, that his hopes were cobwebs and his dreams but mud.  On that day the man sat alone on a park bench and cried.  He did his best not to, knowing that in doing so he would only bleat out his cursed sound over and over and over again.  But his sorrow was too great; it pounded against the dam of his soul and would not be denied.

There was laughter.

Who would be so thoughtless?  Who could be so cruel?  The man peeked out from between his fingers with red-rimmed eyes, only to discover a face that was thoughtless, but not cruel.

"Mister," the little girl said, still laughing.  "That's really funny.  Can you do that again?"

That day the man discovered a new path for himself, a future that would be filled with joyful children.  And, he reflected, was that not an even greater blessing than the one he had originally desired for himself?
----------------------------

On a personal note, the music in Circuits - synthesized voices and electronica - does not hold the greatest appeal for me.  What would I prefer?  Something like Mozart's deathbed scene from 'Amadeus' [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tlPQD04tn88](link)[/url] (forward to 2:00 to see his music start coming together); oh, that would be glorious!  And yet the fact that I enjoyed Circuits so much speaks well of its merits as a game.

---- Pbbt (Epilogue) ------

Of course it was not a greater blessing.  The man remained lost and in love.

Yet the laughter of children did make him happy, and if it was not the greatest happiness he could imagine - well, those who fly too close to the sun often plummet to their death.

Still, for the rest of the life, the man woke from dreams where he sang to rapturous applause - "[i]O Freunde, nicht diese Töne!  Sondern lasst uns angenehmere anstimmen, und freudenvollere.[/i]"  When his eyes blinked open, sometimes he would lie silent.  Sometimes he would wipe tears from his eyes.  And sometimes he would smile and grasp the fleeting substance of his dream, using what was left behind to light the shadowed places of his soul.
----------------------------

This is no rhythm game, this is a musical game. Solving a puzzle means composing a musical piece from short snippets, layered on several tracks (you get extra symbols for bass, drums, solo etc.). The game has the awesome property that a song that doesn't solve the puzzle (i.e. doesn't copy the target piece) still sounds great -- that requires close listeneing to figure out where you were wrong, and also makes the game very enjoayable to play throughout. After all, if it still sounds great, can you really say you were wrong?

If you have an ear for music, listen to the trailer, and if you enjoy that synthetic sound, go for the game. 
If you don't have an ear for music, stay away from this game: you'll be solving it by trial and error, if at all, and that's no fun.

Que delícia de jogo!

Sim, não é simplesmente um jogo "bom". Ele é agradável. Relaxante. Vai na contramão da maioria dos jogos, que geralmente superestimulam o cérebro com exigëncias de reflexos rápidos, raciocínio complexo, luzes piscantes e sons impactantes. Tudo nesse jogo é minimalista, clean, simples - o visual, a trilha, a jogabilidade. É um jogo perfeito para pegar após um dia estressante de trabalho. 

Os puzzles, até onde cheguei (estou aproximadamente na metade do jogo enquanto escrevo este review - *edit: terminei e realmente quase todos os estágios são entre ridiculamente fáceis e razoavelmente fáceis, só um me deu algum trabalho) são fáceis. 9876421.review:
For the price of upto $3, I think the game is overall worth it. It's a nice experience, although short and not too challenging gameplay wise, it's a relaxed casual music game with great music that's enjoyable to listen to.

Sadly, it gets boring to listen to the same song over and over while trying to find out what node you were wrong with, and when you finally get it right, you'll just skip the song because you've heard it so many time until that moment of actual victory.
I think it would've been better if the song were to remain 'bland' (only the nodes you put in, no extra music), and when you actually try to play it (to check if you were correct) it adds all the other layers, to feel some measure of success and progression.

Apart from that, having actual parts of music development that don't occur from the nodes you've placed is rather confusing at points and there should at least be a way to disable that while testing out your song (apart from switching between layers).
At times it was hard to figure out which node was playing what type of music, and some nodes were mostly too quiet to hear and comprehend which required me to guess and check with the hint tool if I was correct or not.

The game doesn't really have any replayability, because once you've finished all 25 levels (I think I finished them in about an hour or two), you've heard all the songs and you wouldn't really go back to play those songs again.
There should be some sort of difficulty level per song (maybe something like 'easy' 'medium' 'hard') which include more/less nodes according to the difficulty, and more song complexity accordingly. Some sort of rating (according to time or some other measurement of performance) may improve replayability.

Lastly, a 'free-creation' mode would've been great, using all the nodes in the game to create your own levels or songs to share, or just to enjoy on your own. That would've changed the game immensly, making it a whole new experience.

Overall, it's a pretty nice game, lacks in a lot of respects, but for $3 it's pretty worth it just to give it a try, and hope the developers will make a 2nd version with some gameplay improvements :P

   Circuits is a music/puzzle game.  It is heavily music based, and headphones

9859256.review: Circuits is a game where it tests your aural skills and is damn well challenging. As a student for sound design, I feel it helped my a little in sharpening my critically hearing. I can't complain that it's two dollars.

9859052.review:
pretty simple puzzle game, gives a tiny bit of insight into structure of typical music although they are short and sometimes off kilter little pieces of music (i.e. consisting of less fulfilling/obvious chord progressions maybe in order to add a bit more difficulty)

pretty neat for the extremely low price

9857983.review: Honestly, I was a little skeptical about this game. After hearing the soundtrack for FEZ I didn't think anything would compare. The music in this game is incredible, not only that but you get to participate in making the music! Such a fun game for such a low price. It puts you in a whole new world. It really gives you a sense of what music was meant to be, and what it is. Personally, I felt the beauty of God in it and I could listen to the soundtrack for hours! Put a soundtrack for sale! :) Get this game people!

9857274.review: The game puts you at ease but also makes you listen. worth 2.39 or 2.99

9857239.review: Not too much here, but it's an excuse to listen to some Chillstep while having a beer. For $2 or less, I can't complain. ;)

9857106.review: Absolute bliss, the sounds used to create each track are bautiful, and even how frustrating it may be the end product is very rewarding. All it needs now is a sandbox mode. 10/10

9857023.review: Took a chance on a release-day indie game and it came through.  This is immensely satisfying to play, and the puzzles seem complex enough to play through 3-4 times before starting to memorize them.  Very worth the price they're asking for!

9856644.review: Interesting game, but got old quickly

9856485.review:
"As we love music, wanted to make a game that gives an insight into how music is created"
After reading this, I thought it would be a very interesting game that sought to be educational. However, after completing the first 10 levels, I found it was little more than placing the appropriate samples ino the correct places. When you place them wrongly, it simply tells you that something is wrong and you have to go back, find it and fix it. There's no idication of why what you did was wrong musically, in terms of harmony or scales or chords. There's no tuition. And so I don't think they achieved what they wanted in this game.

9856193.review: It mixes music with puzzle mechanics, in a really nice and clever way. Worth your time and money.

9845903.review: I went into this game knowing nothing about it, and came out of it extremely satisfied. The puzzles are simply amazing, if just a tad difficult. The minimalistic design is pretty well done, fitting the tone of game. The music is amazing, and pretty catchy, though it can get annoying at times due to having to relisten to it over and over in order to solve a puzzle. This happens very few times however. I guess the biggest complaint one can have is the length of only 25 levels, but for $3, it is well worth the price. However, since the main concept it do put pieces of music together, a musically challeneged person might not find enjoyment in this. Also, I can only assume that the better the headphones, the more complete an experience(also making the puzzles easier I guess), so make sure you have a good pair.

9845733.review: The best part is its cheap. But the game play is way to simple. I blew through all the levels in my first play through and it offer zero replayability. Some of the music is pretty nice but to short to really get into. Buy it if you want but I have seen far better music based games out there then this.

9845012.review: The music in this game is beautifully composed. The puzzle element is simple yet challenging. I found the game interesting enough to keep me engaged throughout. If you're using speakers or headphones, make sure they're good ones so you can truly appreciate every nuance of the soundtrack. For the price, you're going to get every single penny or cent's worth and more besides. Well worth a buy just for the music alone.

9845006.review: After seeing this game under new releases, I decided to give it a chance due to the fact it was only 2.39. After launching it up, I became engaged and absolutely loved what they were trying to do. In all honesty, for 2.39 (or 2.99 regular price) you are getting one great game. It comes packed with 25 mind bobbling levels that give off an amazing amount of sounds, that creates a great harmony when put together.

9844913.review: This game is pretty awesome, but my expectation was to have a sandbox mode, which would complete this game.

Definitely recommend it!
